Award.AwardTitle: Rooting and Growing the Domestic Plant Phenomics Community: Support for the 2019 Annual Phenome Conference, Tucson, Arizona, February 6-9, 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
The annual Phenome 2019 Conference will be held February 6-9, 2019 in Tucson, Arizona . The conference is designed to accelerate U.S. research in the emerging field of phenomics, defined as an interdisciplinary science that allows for in-depth and rapid analysis of plant traits and their response to the environment at an agricultural scale. The conference highlights cutting-edge engineering, sensing and robotic technologies that help plant scientists understand how genome sequences and environmental influences impact plant traits of interest. The four-day meeting will feature plenary talks, technical and networking sessions, and it will provide opportunities for meaningful engagement among plant and crop scientists, engineers and computational scientists. The interdisciplinary meeting is a joint effort of the National Plant Science Council (NPSC), the American Society of Plant Biologists (ASPB) and the North American Plant Phenotyping Network (NAPPN). With NSF support, the conference will continue to attract early career researchers and participants from groups underrepresented in science. The outcomes will be publications in a special journal issue of a relevant journal highlighting advances in phenomics at the interface of biology and engineering. The long-term outcomes will be the establishment of a critical interdisciplinary community in research that increases U.S. agricultural competitiveness and ensures food security now and into the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phenomics is a newly emerging field of interdisciplinary plant science that has direct relevance to agriculture and ecology. Comprising biologists, computational scientists, engineers, and others, phenomics focuses on understanding how genetic variation and natural or manmade environments influence plant growth and productivity.  The field is characterized by the integration of agronomy and plant science with engineering and computer science to drive innovations in automated imaging, sensing technologies, and analytics that deliver vast amounts of data. These data and the application of the information we derive from them help advance U.S. interests in precision agriculture. This happens, for example, through the development of AI and other models that evaluate and predict crop growth, whether from the perspective of individual plant characteristics or with an eye toward environmentally sound management practices. Such advances will be crucial to enhancing world food security in the face of unstable and changing climate conditions. The U.S. lags behind Europe and Australia in this area, and a coordinated acceleration of U.S. research advances using phenomics will require greater communication within the phenomics community, as well as improved capacity to attract and retain promising early-career scientists and engineers who are interested in these tools and their application. The focus of this grant was to reinforce a recurring annual meeting of plant scientists, engineers and computational scientists to share and discuss the latest advances in phenomics technologies and phenomics-driven discoveries. Funds from the award were used to broaden participation and enhance diversity of scientists, particularly junior scientists and women. The meeting was held in Tucson, Arizona, and included three days of seminars and poster sessions, as well as hands-on workshops and other training, conducted by community organizers. Funds supported attendance and research presentations by students, postdocs and junior scientists.

The most important outcome of this support was an extremely high level of enthusiasm from attendees about the quality of the meeting, including increased buy-in from engineering and computer science disciplines, leading us to great excitement about future annual meetings.
